bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to F.M. Boldridge, January 14, 1922

div1.p: Carter writes to Boldridge concerning Geiger's pamphlet on Anopheles mosquito flight experiment.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to F.M. Boldridge, January 14, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
N. M. C.
Boldridge.
January 14, 1922.
Dr. F. M. Boldridge,
Health Officer,
Chester, S. C.
Dear Doctor Boldridge:
div1.p:
I received the pamphlet on the experimentlal flight of Anopheles
at Lonoke and have delayed answering your letter accompanying it because
until to-day I had expected to see you in Camden next Friday. I am noti-
fied, however, that the case is put off until March.

If you cannot get another copy of the pamphlet I will, of coursse,
return this. What I especially wanted to see in it was the number of
Anopheles that Geiger got after the flight, looking for his stained
ones. I told Mr. MacDonald that it was somewhat in excess of 19,000
and it is here given as 19264: of which 10 were recovered
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
1332
2667
